entry.title: Issue with Sorting in SAC Story Table - BW live model - View mode only
entry.content:
Hi all,
We are facing an issue with sorting in SAC Story tables (both old and New Table Builder).
When more than two dimensions are used and sorting is applied by a measure, it works correctly in Edit mode (and we see on the top that one filter was applied) 
However, in View mode, the sorting does not work and multiple filters (e.g. 93) are applied automatically.

Please let us know if this is a known issue or if there is a recommended workaround.

Thank you.

Edit:

 

View:

entry.content:
Hi!

and after that administrator reveiws the data and then publish it to the model.

 

I thought throught the 'calendar' it can be possible, but now i think actually there's a no functionality like that..

Anyone who dealt with this situation, please give me a good idea!

thank you so much!

entry.title: How to Enable Widget Busy Indicator / Ghost Loading indicator for Custom Widgets in SAC
entry.content:
Hello,

We have created a Bar + Line chart custom widget using Chart.js in SAP Analytics Cloud (Optimized Story Experience).

We want to display the SAC busy indicator whenever the user interacts with the custom widget (for example, on data refresh, filter change, or other interactions).

As per the Custom Widget Developer Guide, custom widgets support viewport loading in the optimized story experience by enabling the following property in the widget JSON:

 

 
"supportsViewportLoading": true

We have enabled this property in our widget JSON. However, when interacting with the widget in view mode, the busy indicator is not shown.

Questions

  1. Is enabling  "supportsViewportLoading": true alone sufficient to trigger the busy indicator?

  2. Do we also need to explicitly fire the customWidgetRenderComplete event, and if so, when exactly should it be fired (after DOM render, after data binding, or after Chart.js rendering)?

  3. Are there any working examples or reference implementations for using viewport loading with custom widgets

  4. If viewport loading does not trigger the busy indicator for interactions, is there any recommended workaround to show a busy indicator for custom widgets?
     

Any guidance or examples would be greatly appreciated.

SAP Analytics Cloud #customwidget #SAC #Chart.js  #

#Optimized Story Experience  #JavaScript 

@Meet_Patel10    @dishantp40 @Chandra_Bhansali

entry.title: Why Trading Firms Running SAP On‑Prem Need SAP Business Data Cloud Now
entry.content:
SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) offers trading organizations a governed, cloud‑based data fabric that unifies on‑premise SAP trading systems (S/4HANA, BW/BW‑PCE) with non‑SAP and OT data to build reusable data products for business consumption, analytics, and AI.[1][2][3][4][5]

***

From siloed trading data to governed data products

Most trading firms run core processes on SAP S/4HANA and BW while capturing key operational technology (OT) and market data in non‑SAP platforms, files, or data lakes.[2][3][6]

Bringing these sources together usually means heavy ETL, point‑to‑point interfaces, and copies of price curves, positions, and risk metrics across BW cubes, SQL marts, and spreadsheets, raising both cost and risk.[2][7][8]

BDC replaces this pattern with a business data fabric where SAP and non‑SAP data remain in place or in low‑cost cloud storage, but are exposed as governed “data products” with shared semantics and lineage.[1][4][8][9]

For trading, this means structured products, positions, P&L, reference data, market curves, and even sensor/OT data can be modeled once and reused by risk, finance, compliance, and commercial teams.[3][4][5]

***

Business benefits for trading organizations

1. End‑to‑end trading insight
- BDC connects S/4HANA trading, BW positions, and non‑SAP feeds (exchanges, brokers, weather, IoT) into unified data products, providing a single, governed view of exposures, margins, and liquidity.[2][3][5]
- Federation and zero‑copy access avoid constant extraction of SAP data into external warehouses, so risk and P&L dashboards and predictive models stay closer to real time.[1][4][8]

 

2. Faster innovation with analytics and AI
- Predefined SAP‑managed data products shorten the path from SAP trading data to analytics, while native integration with Databricks and other platforms lets quants and data scientists build models on governed data, not ad‑hoc exports.[3][4][10]
- Output from AI/ML models (e.g., price forecasts, risk factors, credit scores) can be shared back as BDC data products and consumed by SAP Analytics Cloud, Insight Apps, or custom apps without rebuilding pipelines.[3][4][1]

 

3. Better governance and compliance
- A central catalog, ownership model, and lineage in BDC give auditors and regulators transparency into how key trading metrics (VaR, P&L, limits) are built and where they are used.[1][11][12]
- Consistent access control across SAP and non‑SAP domains reduces the proliferation of unmanaged extracts, helping with data protection and trade surveillance requirements.[1][5][8]

 

***

 

Cost benefits and TCO impact

For organizations already running S/4 and BW on‑premise, BDC primarily improves TCO through reduced integration, storage, and operations cost while opening room to decommission legacy tooling over time.[2][4][8][13]

- Less ETL and data duplication
- The fabric approach lets you virtualize SAP data and only persist what adds value (e.g., harmonized trading positions with third‑party data), cutting replication volumes and integration tool spend.[1][4][8][14]
- SAP cites substantial TCO savings versus DIY data fabrics because Datasphere/BDC bundles integration, modeling, and governance rather than forcing you to assemble and run multiple components yourself.[8][4][7]

- Optimized use of existing SAP BW and S/4 investments
- Reference architectures show how BW content can be translated into transformation flows and then exposed as BDC data products, allowing reuse instead of rebuild, and enabling gradual reduction of BW infrastructure.[2][3][15]
- Integration with SAP S/4HANA (including private cloud editions) is productized, so trading data can be transferred into BDC with less custom work than typical third‑party stacks.[16][1][5]

- Hybrid rather than “big bang”
- A hybrid data strategy lets you keep mission‑critical trading execution close to S/4HANA on‑premise while using BDC for analytics, reporting, and AI, limiting initial migration risk and smoothing spend over time.[17][6][18][13]
- Over the medium term, running analytics in BDC instead of parallel on‑premise warehouses and external BI stacks can shrink infrastructure and license footprints, reducing duplicated costs common in hybrid estates.[2][4][13]

***

Pros and cons of moving trading data to BDC

Pros
- Unified SAP + non‑SAP trading view with shared business semantics.[2][1][5][4]
- Stronger data products for risk, treasury, and front‑office teams, increasing trust and reuse.[3][11][12]
- Cloud‑scale analytics and AI on governed data instead of extracts.[4][10][19]
- Strategic roadmap for BW customers beyond classic on‑premise warehousing.[1][2][15]

Cons / risks
- Potential license and platform overlap if BW, external warehouses, and BDC all run without a decommissioning plan.[7][15][13]
- Need for new skills around data products, cloud security, and governance operating models.[4][20][18]
- Stronger dependence on cloud and vendor roadmaps, which must be balanced with latency, sovereignty, and regulatory constraints in some trading jurisdictions.[6][17][21]

***

#SAPBDC #BusinessDataCloud #SAP #S4HANA #SAPBW #TradingAnalytics #DataProducts #DataFabric #HybridCloud #SAPDatasphere #SAPAnalyticsCloud #FinancialMarkets #RiskManagement #DataStrategy #CloudMigration

Citations:
[1] SAP Business Data Cloud https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud.html
[2] Modernizing SAP BW with SAP Business Data Cloud https://architecture.learning.sap.com/docs/ref-arch/f5b6b597a6/4
[3] Innovating SAP BW in SAP Business Data Cloud - SAP Learning https://learning.sap.com/courses/modernizing-sap-bw-with-sap-business-data-cloud/innovating-sap-bw-in-sap-business-data-cloud
[4] Understanding the benefits and impact of SAP Business ... https://www.consultancy.eu/news/11749/understanding-the-benefits-and-impact-of-sap-business-data-cloud
[5] SAP Business Data Cloud - PwC https://www.pwc.com/gx/en/services/alliances/sap/sap-business-data-cloud.html
[6] What Is an Enterprise Data Fabric, and Why Is a Hybrid ... https://www.abiresearch.com/blog/what-is-an-enterprise-data-fabric-and-why-is-a-hybrid-cloud-approach-vital
[7] SAP BDC (Business Data Cloud): What you need to know https://barc.com/sap-bdc-barc-perspective/
[8] Investing in a Business Data Fabric Architecture: Strategic ... https://www.sap.com/resources/investing-in-a-businesss-data-fabric-architecture-goals-and-roi
[9] SAP Business Data Cloud | All for One Poland https://www.all-for-one.pl/en/whitepapers/sap-business-data-cloud/

entry.title: Scripts in input controls do not take effect in mobile devices (SAP Analytics Cloud)
entry.content:
Hi Experts, 

 
I have some scripts in input controls to dynamically adjust the decimal places of charts and tables in the story. These scripts work well on desktop, but are ineffective on mobile devices. (It seems that all of the input controls are converted to something like story filters on mobile devices...) 
 
Is this the expected behavior? Are there any workarounds to resolve it?
 

Any tips or insights would be appreciated! Thank you in advance.

SAP Analytics Cloud

entry.title: Moving Dimension Comment to the far right of my table widget
entry.content:
Hello,

I am creating a story in SAP Analytics Cloud to support monthly reporting using a table. I would like to use the Dimension Comment feature for this report. However, whenever I add the dimension comment column to the table, it appears at the start of the columns. I need it to display at the end of the table instead.

Is there a way to move the dimension comment column to the end of the table? Or any workaround to achieve this?

Thank you in advance for your help!

So I am wondering whether it is possible to let the story just refresh once after I finished selecting all items in input controls.

Any tips or insights would be greatly appreciated! Thank you in advance.

SAP Analytics Cloud

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud to S4HANA Live Connection CDS view access
entry.content:
Hi,

Does an SAC to S/4HANA Live connection provide access to all CDS views in S/4HANA? We have S4HANA Tunnel Connection with SSO.

I understand that only consumption views are visible, but my question is more from a functional access perspective.

For example, we have below views in S4HANA system.

  • 2 views related to OTC,

  • 2 views related to RTR, and

  • 2 views related to STP

I only have access to OTC in S/4HANA:

Will I be able to see all six views in SAC, with no data access on the RTR and STP views?
Or will I only see the two views related to OTC?

Thanks in advance!

Best regards,
Parag

entry.title: Duplicate records for specific dates in SAP Analytics Cloud import model
entry.content:
Source Connection: SAP ERP

Recently, I noticed that for two specific days in November 2025, the values are exactly doubled. This issue occurs only for few dates, and all other dates are correct.

POV:

Import mode: Update

Data in the source SAP ERP is correct (no duplicates)

The job has been running fine before and after these dates

No changes were made to the model or job around that time

My questions:

How is it possible to get duplicates in Update mode?

What could be the reason for duplication only on specific days?

How can I fix this issue and prevent it in the future?

Any guidance would be highly appreciated.

Thanks in Advance!

entry.title: How to optimize stories in SAC mobile so that users do not see "reloaded due to memory constraint"?
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I've designed a three page story in SAC. For each page I've limited the number of widgets and tried to follow best practices according to help portal (https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/fbe339efda1241b5a3f46cf17f54cdff.html?q=optimize).

However, I still came across "reloaded due to memory constraint" on mobile apps and mobile web pages. The story can load, but when I swipe, sometimes it will reload. And every time I opens it on mobile, it takes like 30~60 seconds. (I found that for some mobile devices, the story loads faster, but for the other they load slower. But I cannot expect all users using the best mobile devices...)

The story works pretty well on computer, the loading could finish in about 10 seconds.

I'd like to ask: for the mobile version of the SAC story, if I don’t want to see the message "reloaded due to memory constraint", how should I control the number of widgets on the page or adjust other content? I’m not quite sure where the threshold lies.

Any tips or insights would be greatly appreciated! Thank you in advance.

SAP Analytics Cloud

entry.title: Scoped Roles in SAC
entry.content:
Hello experts,

I have the following problem in SAC and would be happy if someone could provide a solution on how to deal with it or vote for the change in the Customer Influence Program. This would really help us in the project: 

Name: Scoped Roles in SAC

Request ID: 363937

Link: https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/363937

 
Please describe your improvement request:

Scoped roles (like in the Datasphere) should also be introduced in SAC so that permissions can be controlled more precisely in SAC.

It may also make sense to use spaces such as those in Datasphere to implement the requirements. If necessary, the spaces in SAC and Datasphere could then be mapped.

 

What is the opportunity/problem the request will address?

In SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), granting edit permissions for a folder effectively gives the user edit capabilities across the entire SAC environment. If that user also has access to multiple spaces in SAP Datasphere, they can view all data models because roles in SAC are assigned globally rather than at a granular level. This becomes particularly problematic when sensitive HR data exists in Datasphere, as such data should only appear in a shared story developed by the internal SAP department.

Example Scenario: A user in SAC should:

  • Have view-only permissions for the HR folder to view the Story
  • In another folder, “A,” be able to create their own stories using data from Datasphere Space A.

To access both spaces, the user needs a consume role in Datasphere for each space.
The problem: Once the user has edit rights in any folder, they can also view the HR data model because they have a edit permission from a different Folder, which should not be visible.

What is the expected benefit?

The added value is better control of permissions in the SAC and thus better self-service that can be offered.

Thank You and Regards 

Niels

entry.title: How to pass filters between different stories in SAC
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am currently building several SAC stories, which include an overview story (Story A) and multiple sub-stories (Story B, Story C, and Story D). All these stories share 5 identical filters.

In Story A, I have configured 5 input controls and use the NavigationUtils.openStory script to pass the selected filter values from Story A to Stories B, C, and D. Conversely, I have added hyperlinked buttons in Stories B, C, and D to allow users to jump back to Story A.

Here is the typical user workflow: First, users access Story A, set the required filter values, and then use NavigationUtils.openStory to navigate to the other sub-stories. This script works perfectly well—it automatically creates corresponding story filters in the target sub-stories and passes the selected filter values accurately.

However, a usability issue arises when users jump back to Story A via the hyperlinked buttons: the previously selected filter values in Story A are lost, and the story reverts to its default filter settings configured during the design phase.

I am wondering if there is a more optimized way to design these stories to enhance the overall user experience.

(If I use NavigationUtils.openStory to jump back to Story A, I think it will recreates story filters for Story A, and then I will lose the possibility to select from different filter values and that is not good.)

Any tips or insights would be appreciated! Thank you in advance!

SAP Analytics Cloud

entry.title: IAS Login Name dependencies
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

Quick question about the Login Name field in IAS:

Does it matter what I enter here? I often see an email address, but could I also use an employee ID or a short name?

Are there SAP applications or scenarios that require the "Login Name" to be a specific attribute (e.g. Email), or is the field completely flexible?

I want to avoid SSO issues with specific apps if the value is wrong. Does anyone have experience with dependencies for this field?

Many Thanks

Best Regards
